statement-noun.title: statement
statement-noun.definition: a clear expression of something in speech or writing.
statement-noun.contextualMeaning: A spoken or written sentence that expresses a fact or opinion.
statement-noun.exampleSentence: Innit is a short form of 'isn't it', which can be used at the end of a statement for emphasis.

emphasis-noun.title: emphasis
emphasis-noun.definition: special importance, value, or attention given to something.
emphasis-noun.contextualMeaning: Adding force or importance to words.
emphasis-noun.exampleSentence: He also said innit, which is short for 'isn't it', to emphasise what he'd said.

negative-adjective.title: negative
negative-adjective.contextualMeaning: Describing behavior that is not good or helpful.
negative-adjective.exampleSentence: explain the reasons for someone else's (negative) behaviour

unspecified-adjective.title: unspecified
unspecified-adjective.contextualMeaning: Things that are not named or detailed.
unspecified-adjective.exampleSentence: The idiom this and that can be used to describe various unspecified things.

various-adjective.title: various
various-adjective.definition: more than one; of different kinds.
various-adjective.exampleSentence: The idiom this and that can be used to describe various unspecified things.

politeness-noun.title: politeness
politeness-noun.definition: behavior that shows good manners and respect for others.
politeness-noun.contextualMeaning: Acting in a respectful and kind way to others.
politeness-noun.exampleSentence: In this programme, we're talking about politeness.

politeness-adjective.title: polite
politeness-adjective.contextualMeaning: Behaving in a way that is respectful and kind.
politeness-adjective.exampleSentence: Why do we teach children to be polite?

reputation-noun.title: reputation
reputation-noun.definition: the beliefs or opinions that are generally held about someone or something.
reputation-noun.contextualMeaning: How people generally see a country or person.
reputation-noun.exampleSentence: Britain has a reputation for being a polite place.

rude-adjective.title: rude
rude-adjective.contextualMeaning: Speaking or acting in a way that offends others.
rude-adjective.exampleSentence: I'm sorry. That was a bit rude.

well-known-adjective.title: well-known
well-known-adjective.contextualMeaning: Someone famous or recognized by many.
well-known-adjective.exampleSentence: Michael Rosen, who is a well-known poet and children's author in Britain.

recently-adverb.title: recently
recently-adverb.exampleSentence: Recently, this is how it went: a boy was walking past me in the street.

innit-interjection.title: innit
innit-interjection.definition: (slang) a short form of 'isn't it', often used at the end of a statement for emphasis.
innit-interjection.contextualMeaning: An informal way to add emphasis or ask for agreement.

thingy-noun.title: thingy
thingy-noun.definition: (informal) used when you cannot remember someone's or something's name.
thingy-noun.contextualMeaning: A casual word used when a specific name is forgotten.

recognised-verb.title: recognised
recognised-verb.definition: identified someone or something from having encountered them before.
recognised-verb.contextualMeaning: To know someone from past experience.
recognised-verb.exampleSentence: He used the word thingy because, although he recognised Michael, he couldn't remember his name.

poet-noun.title: poet
poet-noun.contextualMeaning: An author known for writing poetry.
poet-noun.exampleSentence: Michael Rosen, who is a well-known poet and children's author in Britain.

impolite-adjective.title: impolite
impolite-adjective.contextualMeaning: Showing a lack of good manners.
impolite-adjective.exampleSentence: So, was the boy being impolite or was he just happy meeting a famous person in the street?

perceived-verb.title: perceived
perceived-verb.definition: understood or interpreted something in a particular way.
perceived-verb.contextualMeaning: How something was understood or seen.
perceived-verb.exampleSentence: I think the crucial thing there is in how you've perceived it.

conventional-adjective.title: conventional
conventional-adjective.definition: based on or in line with what is generally done or believed.
conventional-adjective.contextualMeaning: Following normal or expected rules of behavior.
conventional-adjective.exampleSentence: obviously he's not giving us the conventional: 'Oh, good afternoon, Mr Rosen,' or a more formal approach.

interpreted-verb.title: interpreted
interpreted-verb.definition: explained the meaning of something; understood something in a particular way.
interpreted-verb.contextualMeaning: How something was understood or explained.
interpreted-verb.exampleSentence: Now, that has been interpreted by you as non-threatening to you.

non-threatening-adjective.title: non-threatening
non-threatening-adjective.definition: not causing any feeling of being in danger or under attack.
non-threatening-adjective.contextualMeaning: Not making someone feel afraid or in danger.
non-threatening-adjective.exampleSentence: Now, that has been interpreted by you as non-threatening to you.

aggressive-adjective.title: aggressive
aggressive-adjective.definition: ready or likely to attack or confront.
aggressive-adjective.contextualMeaning: Acting in a forceful and sometimes hostile way.
aggressive-adjective.exampleSentence: You haven't interpreted it as offensive or aggressive.

offensive-adjective.title: offensive
offensive-adjective.definition: causing someone to feel hurt, angry, or upset.
offensive-adjective.contextualMeaning: Something that is rude and makes someone feel bad.
offensive-adjective.exampleSentence: Michael Rosen didn't feel that the boy was insulting him. To insult someone means to be rude or offensive to them.

benefits-noun.title: benefits
benefits-noun.definition: an advantage or profit gained from something.
benefits-noun.exampleSentence: Louise thinks that by teaching our kids politeness they enjoy the benefits of being accepted in society.

repeatedly-adverb.title: repeatedly
repeatedly-adverb.exampleSentence: her two-year-old daughter repeatedly ignored the cook at her nursery school.

nursery-noun.title: nursery
nursery-noun.definition: a place where young children are cared for during the day.
nursery-noun.contextualMeaning: A school or place for very young children.
nursery-noun.exampleSentence: her two-year-old daughter repeatedly ignored the cook at her nursery school.

refused-verb.title: refused
refused-verb.definition: said that one will not do something or accept something.
refused-verb.contextualMeaning: To say 'no' to an action or request.
refused-verb.exampleSentence: her two-year-old daughter repeatedly ignored the cook at her nursery school and refused to say hello.

disappointed-adjective.title: disappointed
disappointed-adjective.definition: sad or displeased because someone or something has failed to fulfill hopes or expectations.
disappointed-adjective.contextualMeaning: Feeling let down or unhappy when something does not happen as expected.

mention-verb.title: mention
mention-verb.definition: refer to something briefly and without detail.
mention-verb.contextualMeaning: To speak about something quickly, without going into much detail.
mention-verb.exampleSentence: And as I mention in the book, it felt to me like there were lots of other children skipping.

kitchen-noun.title: kitchen
kitchen-noun.definition: a room or area where food is prepared and cooked.
kitchen-noun.contextualMeaning: The place in a home or building where food is made.
kitchen-noun.exampleSentence: I felt awful walking back past the kitchen on my way out.

recap-verb.title: recap
recap-verb.definition: to state again the main points of something.
recap-verb.contextualMeaning: To quickly review the main ideas.
recap-verb.exampleSentence: Now, let's recap the vocabulary we've learnt.

learnt-verb.title: learnt
learnt-verb.exampleSentence: Now, let's recap the vocabulary we've learnt.

worksheet-noun.title: worksheet
worksheet-noun.definition: a piece of paper with questions and exercises for students.
worksheet-noun.contextualMeaning: A document with tasks for learning or practice.
worksheet-noun.exampleSentence: test yourself with the programme quiz and worksheet, available now on our website.

quiz-noun.title: quiz
quiz-noun.contextualMeaning: A short set of questions to check understanding.
quiz-noun.exampleSentence: test yourself with the programme quiz and worksheet, available now on our website.

available-adjective.title: available
available-adjective.definition: able to be used or obtained.
available-adjective.contextualMeaning: Ready to be found or used.
available-adjective.exampleSentence: test yourself with the programme quiz and worksheet, available now on our website.
